instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3660: What is 820-3660? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.Q7010: What is Q7010? Q7010 controls whether or not PPDCIN_G3H will be let through to the PP3V42_G3H power supply, often this circuit area is not working because D7010 has died or corroded. .
definitions.D7010: What is D7010? Diode between ground and gate of Q7010 on 2013-2015 year retina model macbook pros, necessary for Q7010 to allow PPDCIN_G3H to flow through to PP3V42_G3H power supply input. When this diode dies or corrodes, PP3V42_G3H input will not have any voltage, and chargers will not turn on. This can often be the problem if a system only works with a knockoff charger/bench power supply. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3660</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-03 Dim green light, no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi,

On an original AC I get just a dim green light, no voltage on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>

~16.5V on both pin 4 + 5 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR>, ~0.2mV on drain

I've replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR> with same result.

Running off of bench power initially saw a quarter fan spin (Hasn't happened since) and only drawing 0.18A, also initially saw ~10V on the drain of <TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR> but slowly dropped and hasn't come back.

Not sure what other information would imediately help, any pointers appreciated.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3660</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-03 Dim green light, no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: 3662 board I assume? What is the history? On bench supply is PP3V42 present?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3660</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-03 Dim green light, no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Sorry for the confusion there, it certainly is a 3662
I wasn't getting anything on PP3V42 on bench power either.
It was left with me for issues not powering up, had liquid damage around the thunderbolt and USB port

Thanks

<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3660</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-03 Dim green light, no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I'm at a loss on this one, hoping someone can help. Getting close to the deadline with this customer

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3660</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-03 Dim green light, no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3660</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-03 Dim green light, no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3660</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-03 Dim green light, no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<DIODE>D7005</DIODE> has 2 inputs, why not just post voltage on all 3 pins....

Voltages on <TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3660</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-03 Dim green light, no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR> - 18.17V Pin 4, 18.46V Pin 5, 0V Pin 1 (Sorry, should have been 0.2mV in my original post, not 0.2V)
<DIODE>D7005</DIODE> - 0V Pin 1, Pin 2, Pin 3

I'm assuming the cold temperature this morning could explain the small discrepancy from yesterdays readings

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3660</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-03 Dim green light, no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Starting to look like a bad <DIODE>D7010</DIODE>. Check voltages on both sides of <RESISTOR>R7011</RESISTOR>, the side that is connected to <DIODE>D7010</DIODE> should have 6.8V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3660</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-03 Dim green light, no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
18.2V on both sides of <RESISTOR>R7011</RESISTOR>, I'll look for a replacement zener for <DIODE>D7010</DIODE>, hopefully have a donor here.

Thanks Duke!
